analysis.title: Recount
analysis.author: Danny Strong
analysis.logline: During the 2000 US Presidential Election, Gore campaign operative Ron Klain battles Republican operatives through a nerve-wracking 36-day legal and political struggle to determine the winner in Florida.

concept.justification: Compelling dramatization of a pivotal moment in modern American electoral history, with inherent dramatic tension and real-world stakes

structure.justification: Meticulously constructed narrative with clear progression, escalating tension, and a documentary-like precision tracking complex legal and political maneuvering

protagonist.justification: Ron Klain is a nuanced, driven character with clear goals, moral complexity, and a profound sense of democratic idealism

supporting_cast.justification: Ensemble of richly drawn real-life figures with distinct personalities and motivations, each contributing to narrative complexity

dialogue.justification: Sharp, witty dialogue that feels authentically political while maintaining dramatic momentum

genre_execution.justification: Masterful handling of complex political procedural, maintaining suspense despite audience knowing historical outcome

originality.justification: Fresh perspective on a well-known historical event, offering intimate behind-the-scenes insights

target_audience.note: Political drama enthusiasts, history buffs, older demographics

high_concept.note: Instantly understandable premise with built-in dramatic tension

cast_attachability.note: Multiple compelling roles for prestigious actors

marketing_hook.note: Dramatic retelling of a pivotal moment in American democracy

budget_return_ratio.note: Moderate budget with potential for critical acclaim

comparable_success.note: Similar to critically successful political dramas

structure_analysis.act_breaks: Election Night, Recount Initiation, Legal Battles, Supreme Court Conclusion
structure_analysis.pacing: fast, propulsive with constant forward momentum

characters.protagonist: Ron Klain - Gore campaign operative, driven by democratic idealism and professional integrity
characters.antagonist: James Baker - Republican operative representing Bush's legal team

standout_scenes.scene: Initial election night confusion and potential recount discovery
standout_scenes.why: Captures the genuine chaos and uncertainty of the moment
Masterful dramatization of legal complexity and high-stakes negotiation

comparable_films.title: All the President's Men
comparable_films.similarity: Political procedural with intense investigative focus

comparable_films.title: The Post
comparable_films.similarity: Historical political drama with institutional tension

budget_tier.justification: Period piece with ensemble cast, requires high-caliber actors and production design

assessment.recommendation_rationale: Exceptional screenplay demonstrating extraordinary craft, historical significance, and dramatic execution. Weighted score of 8.80 with no critical failures and commercial viability score of 15/18.

film_now_assessment.lightning_test: Election night confusion revealing potential massive electoral discrepancy
goosebumps_moments: Page 201: Team's applause for Klain after Gore's concession
Page 165: Craig Waters reading Florida Supreme Court ruling
film_now_assessment.career_risk_test: Absolutely. Represents pinnacle of political procedural storytelling.
film_now_assessment.legacy_potential: Will be studied as definitive dramatic account of 2000 election crisis

analysis.verdict_statement: FILM NOW: RECOUNT represents exceptional material that demands immediate greenlight consideration. The Lightning: A nail-biting, moment-by-moment reconstruction of democracy's most contested hour. The Craft: Weighted score of 8.80 with no dimension below 8. The Commercial Case: CVS of 15/18. George Clooney or Ryan Gosling as Klain presents irresistible star potential. Urgency: This screenplay will not remain available.
